This patch makes the checkpointing of the index query more granular but ensures that any resources being used are correctly released if there is a timeout.

I have also deleted two classes that were not being used.
Using the existing stringifyFileSize seems like the right approach.

I would add [this](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-19197?focusedCommentId=17796104&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-17796104)

The new full coverage is nice. Wouldn't you like to preserve the section you removed commented with `This code won't run until 2086`? I know it does nothing for the test _but_ it helps greatly understand what the test is doing. Otherwise it's a loose end and open door for a future reader to be wondering what about that. It's almost like documentation. I would at least add a comment to help a future reader close the circle and connect all the dots. Wdyt?
I would remove all references to C* v4. You don't know how this play out in trunk, future versions and it will be another thing easy to miss
I dropped a comment on removing references to specific versions but other than that let's fire CI imo

I suspect it's because https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/tree/cassandra-test - a branch used by cqlshlib test - does not support vector type.

@bschoening Thanks for the review!

PEP-495 did bring about that change. But, to get the expected behavior, `astimezone()` should be called on "aware" datetime objects. When you call `astimezone()` on a naive datetime object, it assumes the object to be in the system timezone. The Datastax driver gives out naive UTC datetime objects---`trace.started_at` and `event.datetime` directly come from the CQL queries from [here](https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/blob/master/cassandra/query.py#L1004) and [here](https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/blob/master/cassandra/query.py#L1029).

> If self is naive, it is presumed to represent time in the system timezone.

Here's an example that illustrates the problem. Assume it is `00:00` in New York, which corresponds to `05:00` in UTC.

```python
>>> utc_naive = datetime.datetime(2023, 11, 25, 5, 0, 0)
>>> print(utc_naive)                   # this is what we get from the driver
2023-11-25 05:00:00
>>> print(utc_naive.astimezone())
2023-11-25 05:00:00-05:00              # which is wrong; it should be 12AM in New York


>>> utc_aware = utc_naive.replace(tzinfo=timezone.utc)
>>> print(utc_aware)
2023-11-25 05:00:00+00:00
>>> print(utc_aware.astimezone())
2023-11-25 00:00:00-05:00             # this is correct
```

https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/jacek-lewandowski/cassandra/1213/workflows/2f85e188-f1e5-4db6-b13b-fee016d208c4

https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/jacek-lewandowski/cassandra/1213/workflows/e196c050-478c-42f9-a2bc-64e62e5844de

> I suspect it's because https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/tree/cassandra-test - a branch used by cqlshlib test - does not support vector type.

Yes, it seems we are going to need to update that branch before we proceed with this, probably in a separate ticket.

We could work around it by using this hated literal instead of a reference to `VectorType` but running tests for https://github.com/apache/cassandra/tree/trunk/pylib directory with a not-compatible driver will hit us again eventually.

I doubt we will be able to afford the luxury of updating [this](https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/tree/cassandra-test) particular branch as that will break old versions that do not support python 3. More likely we will have to create yet another branch or use master.
@belliottsmith Hi Benedict, I think we are really close to fixing it! :-) Would you mind taking one last look?

@arkn98 thanks for the very helpful explanation and links. It seem the driver is out-of-sync with Python 3 and should be returning aware object in UTC.

Could you add a comment to datetime_from_utc_to_local that this function is necessary because the driver doesn't set the UTC timezone, which is required before converting to local time zone.

@bschoening I think it is an intentional design choice (at least in the Datastax drivers). They talk about the reasoning [here](https://docs.datastax.com/en/developer/python-driver/3.28/dates_and_times/#timestamps-cassandra-datetype) and [here](https://docs.datastax.com/en/developer/java-driver/4.17/manual/core/temporal_types/#timestamp).

I see, but the python driver docs are out of date -- pytz is no longer relevant with Python 3.9+ and shouldn't be used after EOL for 3.8 in Oct 2024.  

Renovating datetime_from_utc_to_local, as your PR does, aligns it with more modern python use of timezones.  Thanks for your contribution.

It's nothing. And, I took so long. Thanks for putting up with me :sweat_smile:

I'll add that comment to the function. Should I add anything else to this PR (like test cases)?
Since datetime_from_utc_to_local (now) just chains two stdlib functions, I don't see a benefit to unit tests for it.
Alright. The PR is ready for review. I'm not sure what to enter for "Test and Documentation Plan" on the Jira ticket.
@arkn98 Were you able to test it manually?  You can put a comment in the Test and Documentation field and change the status to 'Submit Patch'.
@blambov I've applied your remarks, is ok now?
@bschoening, One quick question. I just saw the `display_timezone` config. Shouldn't the tracing info also be printed using that value, instead of the local timezone?

@smiklosovic I rebased on trunk and picked up the Harry changes.  What do we need to do to move this forward?

@michaelsembwever short answer is: no,  I did not use the script.  I have fixed the issues.

As I noted in Slack (and here for public record) 

I didn't know that what it was for.  I will have to update the 'change dependencies' documentation I recently submitted.

In addition when I tried to run the script on a `Linux 6.2.0-39-generic #40~22.04.1-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Thu Nov 16 10:53:04 UTC 2 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux` system it failed with 2 errors 
`sed: can't read s/cassandra\.classpath\.jars\">.*<\/property>/cassandra\.classpath\.jars\">NEW_CLASSPATH<\/property>/: No such file or directory` and a much longer one from the next line with the CLASSPATH but same `No such file or directory` error.  

The SED comands in the script have blank files for script names (the single quotes after the -i as noted below:
```
sed -i '' 's/cassandra\.classpath\.jars\">.*<\/property>/cassandra\.classpath\.jars\">NEW_CLASSPATH<\/property>/' $DIR/project.xml
sed -i '' "s@NEW_CLASSPATH@"$CLASSPATH"@" $DIR/project.xml
```

If I remove the single quotes it works on my system but I am reticent to include this in this fix.

It looks ok, I have one general comment - I think that something like `SystemInfo` should have a kind of a provider so that we can easily mock it in tests. Maybe something similar to the clock provider.

The latest changes DO NOT implement a provider, and do not expose the underlying SystemInfo implementation.

I still need some clarity on whether or not SystemInfo should be an interface with the current code as an implementation.
@Claudenw I'd say it is up to you because SystemInfo looks like something easy to mock.

@Claudenw I dont think we need an interface for this. It is not like it is a hobby to change the guts of this every quarter or some custom impls would be necessary to justify an interface for that. I think that SystemInfo, as is, is mockable already. cc @jacek-lewandowski
yup, just as said, I'm fine with either approach
@Claudenw will you add a provider for SystemInfo?
